Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for the 2018 International Workshop on Bio-Design Automation (IWBDA)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The 10th International Workshop on Bio-Design Automation (IWBDA) 2018 takes place in Berkeley California July 31st to August 3rd and will bring together researchers from electronic design automation (the practice of using computer software to build complex electronics) and synthetic biology (the forward design of novel biological systems using engineering principles). The goal of IWBDA is to make biology more easily, robustly, reliably, and predictably engineered and therefore, tackle challenges in biology and medicine, leading to advances in disease diagnosis, treatment and prevention. This award provides travel assistance for ten undergraduate and graduate students to attend this workshop to present research, participate in a computer programming competition, and network with a large community of industrial and academic researchers. These participants will go on to form the foundation of the field in the future.

Specifically these students will join a wide variety of researchers (120+) from electronic design automation and synthetic biology in a unique context which does not exist elsewhere. They will have access to between twelve and fifteen technical talks over two days, two invited lectures, ten to twenty posters, multiple group discussion sessions, and a featured student programming competition (BDAthlon). This award covers the registration for the workshop as well as partial support for travel and housing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2018 International Workshop on Bio-Design Automation (IWBDA) was held July 31st to August 3rd 2018 at University of California, Berkeley.  IWBDA brought together researchers from electronic design automation (the practice of using computer software to build complex electronics) and synthetic biology (the forward design of novel biological systems using engineering principles).  The goal of IWBDA is to make biology more easily, robustly, reliably, and predictably engineered and therefore, tackle challenges in biology and medicine, leading to advances in disease diagnosis, treatment and prevention.  There were a total of more than 100 participants from major research universities and industry. Approximately half of the participants were graduate student researchers.  In addition to NSF sponsorship, industrial participation was also a key contributor to the quality of the workshop and related discussions. Industrial sponsors included: Twist Bioscience, Raytheon BBN Technologies, digi.bio, DSM, ACS Synthetic Biology, Minres Technologies, Amyris, Teselagen Biotechnology, Agilent, and Cytoscape. 


This workshop had five technical talk sessions: Design Automation, Machine Learning, Standards, Applications, and Modeling. In these sessions there were a total of 15, 20 minute talks selected from peer-reviewed, extended abstracts. These abstracts are archived on the website program. In addition, there were two keynote speakers. They were Dr. Hector Garcia Martin from Berkeley Labs ("Towards a predictive synthetic biology enabled by machine learning and automation") and Prof. Hana El-Samad from the University of California, San Francisco ("Biological control: The versatile ways in which cells use feedback loops").  There were 14 posters presented, a programming contest ("BDAthlon"), and a whole group discussion sessions. ACS Synthetic Biology used submissions as part of a "special issue" highlighting the technical contributions of the workshop.

For more information please see: http://www.iwbdaconf.org/2018/
